title: Canada sets target of admitting 25,000 from overseas - The Economic Times
text: Canada sets target of admitting 25,000 from overseas By Dipanjan Roy Chaudhury , ET Bureau | Updated: Feb 07, 2017, 10.12 AM IST READ MORE ON » Refugee | Immigration | canada India is among top source country for permanent residencies in Canada and in 2016 alone over 32,000 Indians were given permanent residencies by the North American country. Budget 2017: Budget 2017 is out: Read how it impacts you and India NEW DELHI: Canada , unlike neighbouring USA under the new administration and notwithstanding recent attack in Quebec mosque, has set a target of admitting 25,000 refugees from overseas this year, one of highest intake in recent years amid rising number of fleeing people from various war zones. “In 2017, Canada will welcome 25 000 refugees from overseas. This is one of the highest numbers of refugees in Canadian history - double those established for 2015 and in preceding years. We welcome those fleeing persecution, terror and war and those who would like to add their skills to our economy and to our society. Canada also plans to admit 15,000 Protected Persons in Canada and Dependants Abroad,” a senior official in the Canadian Immigration Department told ET from Ottawaamid raging controversy over USA putting travel ban on refugees and visa holders from certain countries besides contemplating tougher regulations for H-1B visas. India is among top source country for permanent residencies in Canada and in 2016 alone over 32,000 Indians were given permanent residencies by the North American country. In 2015 over 39,000 Indians were given PR status by Ottawa. The current Canadian Parliament has 19 MPs of Indian origin and this includes some top Cabinet Ministers. Indians comprise 3.8 per cent of Canada’s population. Canada is also emerging as favorite destination for the Indian students. While admitting either refugees or PR the Canadian government has no plans to lower their guard and compromise on thenecessary security matter. Security screening is an important part of the overall assessment of whether a person is admissible to Canada, according to senior the immigration officials. “We are confident in our immigration programs and will continue to ensure that our immigration system balances compassion, efficiency and economic opportunity, while protecting the health, safety and security of Canadians. The Government of Canada is committed to the safety and security of the Canadian public. All visitors (which include temporary foreign workers and students), immigrants and refugees are carefully screened before coming into Canada…This ensures anyone who wants to come to Canada has not committed serious crimes, does not pose a health or safety risk to Canadians and has a valid passport or travel document.,” pointed out a Canadian government official. Canada has been an attractive destination from across the world including first world and developed country. Immigration has also played a key role in Canada’s economic success over the years. “Immigration plays a key role in contributing to Canada's well-being, to our economic prosperity, and to our success as a nation… We are confident in our immigration programs and will continue to ensure that our immigration system balances compassion, efficiency and economic opportunity, while protecting the health, safety and security of Canadians,” an official in the Canadian Immigration Minister’s office told ET. According to Ahmed D Hussen Canada’s new immigration Minister, "Our principles are openness, open to new ideas, open to people, open to those who want to come here and make a better life for themselves, contribute to our economy through their high skills and to also have the compassion to continue to have the compassion for those who seek sanctuary in our country". Hussen is originally from Somalia who to Canada in 1993 and rose to become a Minister. Canada welcomes immigrants without discrimination from around the world through a variety of immigration programs that support Canada's diversity and helps grow economy, a Canadian official said, adding, the contributions of all newcomers result in jobs, innovation and economic growth.” All applicants who apply to Canada's immigration programs are treated equally no matter where they are from and anyone can emigrate to Canada provided they meet the qualifications, claimed a Canadian immigrant department official who did not wish to be quoted.
